9911.title: purse
9911.description: green and black enamel on silver metal frame, chain with cylinders (once painted green) mesh bag with painted scene in yellow, orange, black, green, bone and aubergince, light green cloth lining
9911.credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Roman J. Radecki
9911.provenance: Mr. and Mrs. Roman J. Radecki, South Bend, Indiana; through Radecki Art Galleries, South Bend, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art (1975).

extended_text.content: The products of the Whiting and Davis Company exemplify in many respects the modern style as it appeared in America about 1930. The first machine for manufacturing chain mail was developed by the factory in 1907; soon it was mass producing great quantities of mesh items, purse accessories and jewelry. Whiting and Davis products are distinguished from lesser imitators by the high quality of their design: even such sophisticated Europeans as Paul Poiret, the Parisian couturier and interior designer, were commissioned to furnish designs for Whiting and Davis handbags. The well-known geometric, stylized patterns on many Whiting Davis purses often executed in vivid colors help to convey to the present-day viewer something of the flavor of the “jazz age.”
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

9911.exhibit_history: exhibition unknown- didactic found in curator's notebook. (PS - 2011)

extended_text.content: The products of the Whiting and Davis Company exemplify in many respects the modern style as it appeared in America about 1930. The first machine for manufacturing chain mail was developed by the factory in 1907; soon it was mass producing great quantities of mesh items, purse accessories and jewelry. Whiting and Davis products are distinguished from lesser imitators by the high quality of their design: even such sophisticated Europeans as Paul Poiret, the Parisian couturier and interior designer, were commissioned to furnish designs for Whiting and Davis handbags. The well-known geometric, stylized patterns on many Whiting Davis purses often executed in vivid colors help to convey to the present-day viewer something of the flavor of the “jazz age.”

66549.title: Six
66549.credit_line: Gift of Ann M. and Chris Stack
66549.medium_support: wood, canvas, acrylic paint, corduroy fabric, nails, florist wire, linen
66549.provenance: Ann M. and Chris Stack, Indianapolis, Indiana; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1994.

33846.title: Talpa
33846.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. T. Victor Keene
33846.provenance: Mrs. T. Victor Keene; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1976.
33846.inscription:
Inscribed in pencil, below image, l.l.:  #68 - Talpa 
Inscribed in pencil, below image, l.c.:  To Victor Higgins / October 15 - 1921
Signed and dated in plate, l.l.: Pearson / May '19
Signed in pencil, below image, l.r.: Ralph Pearson

extended_text.content:
Joining many other Midwestern artists, Pearson was lured to Taos, New Mexico in the early days of that art colony. Settling in nearby Ranchos de Taos in 1919, Pearson created etchings of his environs including this view of the adjacent village of Talpa.

Pearson came west as a trained etcher with his own press. His etchings are among the earliest made at Taos and are far rarer than paintings of that era.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

33846.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

3594.title: dress
3594.description: multi-colored with all over pattern silk brocade dress with asymetrical trim and draping
3594.dimensions:
a) jacket: L: 28 in., 71.1 cm
B) dress: L: 46 1/2 in., 118.1 cm

extended_text.content:
The exquisite brocaded fabric of this dress exhibits a strong East Asian influence. The clusters of roundels contain Chinese motifs, such as plum blossoms, thunder patterns, overlapping waves, and the Chinese character shou, which symbolizes long life. Because plum blossoms bloom in the harshness of winter and continue into early spring, they symbolize vitality and celebrate the arrival of spring.

Beginning in the 1870s and until the early 1890s, the style of skirts changed from the full-bell shape of the 1860s to a half-bell shape, creating a flatter, smoother effect in the front and moving fullness, supported by a bustle, towards the back.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

3594.exhibit_history:
Fashion in Bloom
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 4, 2009 - January 31, 2010

3449.title: Head of Margot
3449.medium_support: pastel on white laid Ingres paper

extended_text.content:
Mary Cassatt received her early training in America but settled in Paris, where she befriended Edgar Degas and exhibited with the Impressionists.

Young children were among Cassatt's favorite subjects, though she avoided sentimental portrayals in favor of emphasizing her models' freshness, intelligence, and energy.

This pastel is one in a series of portraits of children who lived in the French village where Cassatt spent her summers.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

3449.exhibit_history:
Museum of Art, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, Indiana, 01/26/1983-03/13/1983
7th Annual Philadelphia Watercolor Exhibition, Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, 11/08/1909-12/13/1909
24th Annual Exhibition, The John Herron Art Institute, Indianapolis, Indiana, 12/06/1908-01/04/1909|

16563.title: Pelvis with the Distance
16563.credit_line: Gift of Anne Marmon Greenleaf in memory of Caroline Marmon Fesler
16563.provenance: Purchased from the artist by Caroline Fesler; Anne Marmon Greenleaf 1960; donated to the IMA 1977
16563.subject_description: desert landscape with pelvis bone, mountains in background
rights: © Georgia O'Keeffe Museum / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

extended_text.content:
The radical manipulation of perspective and scale, and the strong but elegant contours of the bone, exemplify O'Keeffe's genius for capturing the essential forms of nature.

In 1929 O'Keeffe began to summer in New Mexico, where the colors, shapes, and vistas of the Southwest became central to her work.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

extended_text.content:
Georgia O’Keeffe, the second of seven children, was born on a farm in Wisconsin. O’Keeffe’s mother encouraged her to pursue art. In 1905, she enrolled at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and, beginning in 1907, she attended the Art Students League in New York, studying there under William Merritt Chase. Her first art job was as a commercial artist. A drawing class taught by Alon Bement at the University of Virginia Summer School introduced O’Keeffe to the work of Arthur Wesley Dow, whose progressive ideas influenced her art. In 1916, the New York art dealer, Alfred Stieglitz, first exhibited O’Keeffe’s work in his 291 gallery. The two cultivated a relationship and eventually wed in 1924. O’Keeffe began making compositions of enlarged natural forms, which became her signature style. Between 1929 and 1949, O’Keeffe spent each year working in New Mexico and the region influenced her selection of subject matter. After Stieglitz died, O’Keeffe moved to a home she had purchased in Abiquiu, New Mexico. The Georgia O’Keeffe museum was established in Santa Fe, New Mexico, in 1997, and her home and studio in Abiquiu became a National Historic landmark in 1998.

In Pelvis with Distance, an enormous skeletal form rises majestically from the flat foreground. In the distance, a mountain range defines a low horizon line. O’Keeffe’s radical distortion of scale and perspective is striking in this painting. The foreground is dominated by the bone’s elegant contours, exemplifying O’Keeffe’s genius for capturing the essential forms of nature. O’Keeffe wrote to collector Caroline Marmon Fesler about her bone series, “It is a kind of thing that I do that makes me feel I am going off into space – in a way that I like – and that frightens me a little because it is so unlike what anyone else is doing – I always feel that sometime I may fall off the edge – it is something I like so much to do that I don’t care if I do fall off the edge.”

Lyons, Barbara Buhler, Leslie Polling-Kempes, and Frederick W. Turner. Georgia O’Keeffe and New Mexico: A Sense of Place. Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2004.
extended_text.title: The Formal Experiments of Georgia Oâ??Keeffe

16563.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB: Georgia O'Keeffe and the Southwestern Still-Life, Tacoma Museum of Art, Tacoma, Washington, 03/01/2015-06/07/2015  |  Georgia O'Keeffe: Nature and Abstraction, Vancouver Art Gallery, Vancouver, Canada, 10/06/2007-01/13/2008  | Georgia O'Keeffe: Nature and Abstraction, Irish Museum of Modern Art, Dublin, Ireland, 03/06/2007-05/13/2007  |  Georgia O'Keeffe: Visions of the Sublime, Eiteljorg Museum of American Indians and Western Art, Indianapolis, Indiana, 01/27/2005-04/03/2005  |  Georgia O'Keeffe, Kunsthaus Zurich, Zurich, Switzerland, 10/24/2003-02/01/2004  |  Georgia OKeeffe: The Poetry of Things, The Dallas Museum of Art, Dallas, Texas, 11/07/1999-01/30/2000  |  Georgia O'Keeffe: The Poetry of Things, The Georgia OKeeffe Museum, Santa Fe, New Mexico, 08/07/1999-10/17/1999  |  Georgia O'Keeffe: T Things, The Phillips Collection, Washington, D. C., 04/17/1999-07/18/1999  |  200 Years of American Painting, City Art Museum, St. Louis, Missouri, 04/01/1964-05/31/1964  |  Georgia O'Keefe, Museum of Modern Art, New York, New York, 05/15/1946-08/25/1946  |  Georgia O'Keefe, An American Place, New York, New York, 01/11/1944-03/11/1944  |  The American Scene: The 20th Century, Indiana University Art Museum, Bloomington, Indiana, 04/06/????-05/17/????

31511.title: Portrait of a Young Woman
31511.credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Ball
31511.provenance: Purchased from Max Safron of New York by William H. Ball in Muncie, Indiana; Mr. Ball donated it to the museum in 1977
31511.subject_description: portrait of a young unknown woman

extended_text.content:
The sitter's dress and coiffure reflect the new American aristocracy's desire to legitimize itself through association with historical styles of ancient Greece and Rome.

Stuart's portraits of George Washington and Federalist families in Philadelphia and Washington secured his place in history.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

extended_text.content:
Debt resulting from an inability to manage money kept Gilbert Stuart on the move much of his life. Born in North Kingston, Rhode Island, and raised in Newport, Stuart was taught by a local Scottish painter, who took him to Scotland. His mentor’s death forced Stuart to return to America. During the Revolutionary War, Stuart traveled to England to study with the American expatriate Benjamin West. As success came, so did debt, which forced Stuart to Dublin, Ireland, and then to America, where he eventually became the most highly regarded portraitist of his day. A skillful master of his craft, Stuart painted directly on the canvas without using any preliminary drawing. Stuart was prolific – he painted over one thousand portraits of important political figures. One of his most famous portraits of George Washington was the “Athenaeum Head,” which is currently on the dollar bill.

The conventional pose and accessories in Portrait of a Young Woman are characteristic of Stuart’s work; however, the sitter’s rare loveliness and the influence of French Neoclassicism are exceptional. The Empire style of the girl’s dress and coiffure reflect the taste of the American aristocracy, a class eager to legitimize itself through association with the historical past, specifically ancient Rome.

Barratt, Carrie Rebora, Ellen Gross Miles. Gilbert Stuart. New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2004.
extended_text.title: Portraitist of the American Aristocracy

31511.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

17167.title: The Pioneers
17167.credit_line: James E. Roberts Fund and Emma Harter Sweetser Fund
17167.provenance: The piece was purchased from the Robert Rice Gallery in Houston in 1979
17167.subject_description: landscape of valley with river and two pioneers chopping wood

extended_text.content:
The Pioneers resemble a style of British landscape painting known as "picturesque," which features images such as the shadowy valley, rugged woodcutters, twisted trees and romantic stone ruins.

English-born Shaw painted the branches and leaves with a delicate touch.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

extended_text.content:
Joshua Shaw was born in Bellingborough, Lincolnshire, England, where he apprenticed under a sign painter, simultaneously earning a living and studying art. He worked as a landscape painter in Bath, exhibiting occasionally at the Royal Academy and the British Institution in London. In London, he became acquainted with American expatriate artist Benjamin West. Shaw immigrated to Philadelphia in 1817 to oversee the installation of Benjamin West’s painting Christ Healing the Sick at the Pennsylvania Hospital. In 1819, he traveled with his teenage son to the South to create watercolor scenes of the area that were engraved in acquaint and published as a book, Picturesque Views of American Scenery (1820-1821). After returning to Philadelphia, Shaw created over two hundred oil paintings.

The Pioneers exemplifies the picturesque aesthetic popular among English artists during the late eighteenth and early nineteenth-centuries. The shadowy valley, rugged woodcutters, and twisted trees exhibit striking contrasts of light and dark, rough textures, and intricate forms. Shaw’s scene may be based on the topography of Pennsylvania’s Delaware Water Gap. In another allusion to the picturesque, Shaw fashioned two of the rocky features in the distant valley to resemble the ruins of European castles.

Naeve, John C. et al. 150 Years of Philadelphia Painters and Paintings. Philadelphia: The Library Company of Philadelphia, 1999.
extended_text.title: The Picturesque Aesthetic

17167.exhibit_history: The Beautiful, The Sublime, and The Picturesque, Washington University Gallery of Art, St. Louis, Missouri, (02/18/1984-04/08/1984)

28373.title: Glow of Gold, Gleam of Pearl
28373.provenance: The artist; the wife of the artist and his estate; by bequest to R.H.I. Gammell in Boston, Massachusetts 1971; gift to the museum by Robert Douglas Hunter of Boston 1979

extended_text.content:
Instead of the smooth finish that lends French nudes their remote idealism, this figure is brushed with ruddy reflections of the walls, giving her flesh a sensuous realism, and suggesting Paxton's attraction to Impressionism.

A transitional work, this nude predates most of the elegant interior scenes for which Paxton and his Boston School colleagues are best known.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

extended_text.content:
William Paxton belonged to the Boston School of artists, which included Frank Benson and Edmund Tarbell. He was strongly influenced by the intimate interiors of seventeenth-century Dutch painter Johannes Vermeer. Portraiture and figure studies were Paxton’s specialty. He was also noted for his depictions of upper class life. A consummate draftsman and colorist, Paxton was adept at depicting flesh convincingly. Paxton described his technique, “I let the surfaces flow into one another in a supple envelope of light and paint.”

Glow of Gold, Gleam of Pearl is the masterpiece of Paxton’s early career. A transitional work, it predates most of the elegant domestic scenes for which he is best known. The figure’s silhouette and theatrical pose are reminiscent of Jean Léon Gérôme’s academic paintings, which Paxton would have seen during his training with Gérôme in Paris. Instead of the smooth, idealizing finish characteristic of French nudes, this figure is brushed with a modified impressionist flourish. The model’s ruddy complexion captured as a reflection on the nearby walls give her flesh a sensuous realism.

Lee, Ellen Wardwell, R. H. Ives Gammel, Martin F. Krause, Jr. William McGregor Paxton 1869-1941. Indianapolis Museum of Art, 1979.
extended_text.title: "Envelope of Light and Paint"

28373.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB:  Alaska-Yukon-and-Pacific Exposition, Seattle, Washington, 1909  |  Paintings by William M. Paxton, St. Botolph Club, Boston, Massachusetts, 1909  |  3rd Annual Exhibition, Albright Art Gallery, Buffalo, New York, 1908  |  3rd Annual Exhibition, Museum of Fine Arts St. Louis, St. Louis, Missouri, 1908  |  103rd Annual Exhibition, Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, 1903 - awarded second place popular prize

32644.title: Pack Train
32644.medium_support: pencil heightened with white on tan paper
32644.provenance: Coral Taflinger Black; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1979.

extended_text.content: Blumenschein and Bert Phillips, on an 1898 sketching trip from New York to Mexico, were delayed by a broken wagon wheel outside of the isolated northern New Mexican village of Taos. Finding the surrounding mountain scenery majestic and the thriving Hispanic and Native American cultures paint worthy, they ventured no further. Heeding the invitation of these two artists, others came from the East and by 1915 the Taos art colony was fully established.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

32644.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

36898.title: Venus Anadyomene
36898.creation_notes: According to Maurice Galleries Steinberg (Chicago) information sheet in historical file, Manship cast this bronze in an edition of 20 as well as a larger marble version and life-size marble fountain presented to Phillips Academy (the latter of 1929). See historical file for more information.
36898.credit_line: Gift of Dr. and Mrs. M. D. Ratner
36898.provenance: (Galleries Maurice Sternberg, Chicago, Illinois); purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1979.
36898.inscription: Signed and dated, left side, land form beneath figure's right leg: P • MANSHIP • / © 1924

extended_text.content:
The stylized hair and soft rounded forms are in harmony with the images of the sea, the goddess, and Art Deco sculpture of the 1920s and 1930s.

This small bronze figure is tied to the mythological goddess of love and her birth from the foam of the sea.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

extended_text.content:
Paul Manship’s academic career commenced at the St. Paul School of Art in Minnesota. At the age of nineteen, he moved to Philadelphia to continue his studies at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts. Manship later relocated to New York, where he enrolled at the Art Students League. He also served as an assistant to Solon Borglum, a sculptor of Western themes, from whom he gained knowledge of animal anatomy. Manship won the coveted Prix de Rome and a fellowship to study for three years at the American Academy of Rome. It was at this time that he developed an interest in classical and archaic Greek art. Upon returning to America, these combined influences resulted in a style attractive to both modernists and conservatives in its simplification of line and detail. He created a number of sculptures characterized by a stylized form that was uniquely his own. Manship’s oeuvre includes over 700 works.

Venus’s birth from sea foam, called Venus Anadyomene, is the subject depicted here. The cascade of wavy hair and the figure’s soft, rounded forms are congruent with images of the sea, the goddess, and the Art Deco style. Manship lavished attention on the surfaces of his sculpture. Here, the rich brown coloring has been rubbed away from her hair to add highlights.

Rathner, Susan. Archaism, Modernism, and the Art of Paul Manship. Austin: University of Texas Press, 1993.
extended_text.title: Simplification of Line and Detail

36898.exhibit_history: "Key Acquisitions Since 1970 II" Indianapolis Museum of Art October 21 - November 30 1980

5098.title: Listening to Music
5098.inscription: stamped, verso, C: WEEGEE / 451 WEST 47th STREET / NEW YORK CITY U.S.A. / TEL: 265-1955 stamped, verso, L.R.: CREDIT PHOTO BY / WEEGEE / THE FAMOUS

13034.title: Miss Lemon Drop
13034.provenance: Gerald Rosen, Santa Monica, California, Louis Meisel Gallery, New York, New York
rights: © Licensed by VAGA, New York, NY

extended_text.content: Since the 1960s, Mel Ramos has dedicated his career to painting the female nude. Ramos builds on a tradition of depicting the idealized female nude that dates back to 19th century French salon painting and its predecessors. Intentionally humorous, his works draw on depictions of women from popular culture, such as pin-up calendars, centerfolds and advertisements. He emphasizes these sources by endowing his painted figures with the characteristic sheen of commercial photography, and emphasizing their self-consciously come-hither glances to the viewer. Because of his references to popular culture, his work has been associated with the Pop Art movement that dominated much of the art world in the mid-1960s.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

29377.title: Lower Yellowstone Range seen from Yellowstone National Park
29377.provenance: Purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1980.
29377.inscription: signed, dated and inscribed in stone, L.L.:  T. MORAN/1874/LOWER/YELLOWSTONE RANGE | inscribed in stone, L.C.:  1876 BY L. PRANG & Co BOSTON | inscribed in stone,  L.R.:  PRANG'S AMERICAN CHROMO

extended_text.content:
In 1871 Moran joined the United States Geological Survey as the official artist on the expedition to the largely unexplored Yellowstone region of Wyoming. His drawings helped lead to the establishment of Yellowstone as the first national park in 1872.

Between 1874 and 1876 the Boston publisher Louis Prang issued fourteen chromolithographs translated from Moran’s Yellowstone watercolors, the popularity of which helped shape America’s fascination with the West.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

29377.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

14280.title: Llano Quemado II
14280.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Hiram W. McKee
14280.provenance: Mrs. Hiram W. McKee; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1980.
14280.inscription: initialed in pencil, below image, L.R.:  A. D.

extended_text.content:
Llano Quemado is a small village just south of Dasburg’s home in Ranchos de Taos.

The angular geometry of the New Mexican landscape was well-suited to the Cezannesque style of painting that Dasburg had embraced before moving to New Mexico in 1918.

Dasburg made his first lithographs at the age of 87 at the request of the Tamarind Institute which had recently relocated its print workshop from Los Angeles to Albuquerque, New Mexico.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

14280.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

22251.title: Western River Scenery
22251.credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Ballard in memory of Ed and Dolly Ballard
22251.provenance: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Ballard; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1980.

extended_text.content: Currier & Ives’ Western River Scenery depicts nothing more western than the Mississippi River. Until the end of the 19th century the region between the Appalachian Mountains and the Mississippi was the “West,” and the unpopulated vastness beyond the river was only vaguely comprehended as the “Far West.”
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

22251.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

68617.title: Johnson & Johnson First Aid Kit
68617.description:
White plastic first aid kit (Lot# 0619JR) with paper cover and the following contents: 
1) 2 sterile first aid dressings (Lot # 727609), 2) 1 Bengay pain relieving patch (Lot# G02X8C1), 3) 1 Coach instant cold pack (Lot# 1297E), 4) 1 Omniglow yellow lightstick (Lot# 21P25R/3), 5) 1 pack/cloth Cortaid Poison Ivy care cloths (Lot# 1097KB2), 6) 1 box of 80 assorted sheer comfort-flex Band Aid brand bandages (2 x-large 3 x 2-1/4 in., 30 large 3 x ? in., 34 medium 2 x 1/2 in., 14 small square bandages), 7) 1 box of 30 assorted Band Aid brand bandages (10 waterblock plus clear, 10 tough strips, 10 sport strips), 8) 1 clear plastic container with the following contents:1) 1 first aid guide, 2) 1 plastic tweezer, 3) 2 packs of Sudafed PE nasal decongestant (1 pill each), 4) 2 packs Imodium A-D (2 caplets each), 5) 2 packs Motrin IB (2 caplets each), 6) 1 pack Tylenol Extra Strength (2 caplets), 7) 1 first aid emergency contact magnet, 8) 1 survival wrap (Lot # 1287C), 9) 2 bags plastic gloves, 10) 2 tongue depressors, 11) 1 sterile eye pad (1.6 x 2.6 in.), 12) 5 packets of all purpose sterile dressings (2 x 2 in. each), 13) 12 packs cleansing wipes (Lot# 0467NG), 14) 1 pack Nextemp single-use clinical thermometer (Lot# 04150), 15) 2 large sterile adhesive bandages, 16) 1 pack Cortaid advanced cream (Lot # 22586), 17) 2 packs Neosporin antibiotic ointment (Lot# 0159LZ), 18) 1 box Band-Aid brand bandages (10 large butterfly bandages, 10 "H" bandages, 10 butterfly closures), 19) 1 roll Johnson & Johnson heavy-duty waterproof tape (Lot# 2627B)

65551.title: "Never too old," Hollywood Premiere
65551.credit_line: Caroline Marmon Fesler Fund, Gift of the Alliance of the Indianapolis Museum of Art, Roger G. Wolcott Fund, Nancy Foxwell Neuberger Acquisition Endowment Fund, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore P. Van Vorhees Art Fund, Cecil F. Head Art Fund, James V. Sweetser Fund

65551.exhibit_history: Shots in the Dark: Photos by Weegee the Famous; 04/17/2010 to 01/23/2011

29746.title: needlework mourning picture
29746.description: painted | Embroidered | Silk Threads | Wood Frame
29746.credit_line: Edith A. Venn Fine Arts Purchase Fund
29746.inscription: To the memory of James and Mary Bell this work is respectfully dedicated by their affectionate daughters Ann Finley and Rebecca Bell.

extended_text.content:
This embroidery depicts Rebecca Bell and her sister at the tomb of their parents. The inscription on the tomb reads:

To the memory of James and Mary Bell this work is respectfully dedicated by their affectionate daughters Ann Finley and Rebecca Bell.

The two women are dressed in the fashion of the mid-1790s to early 1800s - free, simple flowing gowns of the period with waistbands tied directly under the bust. The mourning pictures featuring tombs, urns and weeping willows were very popular during the early 19th century, when romantic sentimentality was in vogue.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

29746.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

22824.title: evening ensemble: top, skirt, sash
22824.description: lightwieght material, halter dress with slash opening
22824.provenance: Elizabeth Weymouth, New York (Stan Weaver, New York): given to IMA 1986.

extended_text.content:
This three-piece ensemble was inspired by the orientalist styles of the early 1900s. The halter-top dress is wrapped and tied to the side, creating a pointed, asymmetrical hem. The accompanying top has long puffed sleeves and ties on the hips. A turban completes the ensemble.

The metallic yarns, dyed in subtle shades of silver, lavender and blue-green, create a scintillating effect when the outfit is worn.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

22824.exhibit_history:
Simply Halston
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 13, 2008 - January 4, 2009

All That Gillters
Paul Textile Arts Gallery, IMA

8620.title: evening ensemble
8620.provenance: Elizabeth Weymouth, New York (Stan Weaver, New York): given to IMA 1986.

extended_text.content:
Patterns played an important role in Halston's trademark beadwork for dresses, kaftans and tops. The chiffon fabrics became canvases for an explosion of beads and sequins.

The ingenuity of Halston's designs is evident in the beaded pattern of this dress. The weight of the beads in the fireworks pattern is distributed evenly all over the dress. Since the fabric was cut on the bias, this would prevent it from stretching.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

8620.exhibit_history:
Simply Halston
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 13, 2008 - January 4, 2009

All That Glitters
Paul Textile Gallery, IMA

23558.title: evening ensemble
23558.title_notes: A) jacket, B) halter top, C) dress, D) pants
23558.description: custom design beadwork and embroidery, cardigan jacket
23558.medium_support: synthetic fabric, silk chiffon, bugle beads
23558.provenance: Elizabeth Weymouth, New York (Stan Weaver, New York): given to IMA 1986.
23558.dimensions:
A) L: 30 (jacket)
B) L: 44 (halter top)
C) L: 33 (dress)
D) L: 45 in. (pants)

extended_text.content:
This long-sleeve cardigan jacket is worn with a silk chiffon double-layer halter top tied into a bow at the front. Straight-leg trousers, gathered into a wide elastic waistband, complete the ensemble.

The custom-designed beadwork features a swirling pattern, which is used throughout the main field. The bottom parts of the jacket and trousers are embroidered in a wave pattern.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

23558.exhibit_history:
Simply Halston
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 13, 2008 - January 4, 2009

All That Glitters
Paul Textile Gallery

7947.title: The Indian Detour
7947.provenance: Purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1987.
7947.inscription: inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.:  100 proofs/To Mrs. Hatfield/John Sloan N.Y.C. 1929 | inscribed in pencil, below image, L.C.: The Indian Detour | signed in pencil, below image, L.R.:  John Sloan
rights: © Delaware Art Museum/ Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

extended_text.content:
The Indian Detour was the name of bus tours organized by the Fred Harvey Company in 1926 that transported tourists from the Harvey House Hotels along the Santa Fe Railway to various Pueblo ceremonies.

Joan Sloan, who had established a summer home in Santa Fe in 1920, like many other resident artists, found these bus tours such gawking intrusions into sacred Native American rituals that he lampooned them in this etching.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

7947.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

23772.title: Suspended Disc II
23772.credit_line: Gift of the Contemporary Art Society

23502.title: The Three Chiefs, Piegan
23502.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Charles E. Rogers
23502.provenance: Mrs. Charles E. Rogers; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1988.
23502.inscription: signed and inscribed on plate, L.R.: Curtis/L.A. c

extended_text.content:
Curtis visited the Piegan (Blackfeet) in northern Montana in 1900, his first encounter with Native Americans whose culture was largely intact.

Besides the select images that Curtis produced as orotones for collectors, his major effort was the publication of The North American Indian. This opus was published between 1907 and 1930 in 20 volumes, illustrated with over 700 of Curtis’ photographs and containing millions of words descriptive of all features of Indian life.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

23502.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

27264.title: The Vanishing Race
27264.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Charles E. Rogers
27264.provenance: Mrs. Charles E. Rogers; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1988.
27264.inscription: signed and inscribed on plate, L.R.: Curtis/L.A. c

extended_text.content:
Edward Curtis began his photographic documentation of the Plains, Northwest Coast and Southwest Native American peoples in 1899. In a typical work such as his view of the Navajo, called “Vanishing Race,” he treated the Indian as a romantic figure of the past rather than of the present.

The orotone process was popularized by Curtis. The negative was printed on the back of the frame’s glass and dusted with gold pigment to produce a translucent, nostalgic image.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

27264.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012

1640.title: La Grande Bataille
1640.provenance: Purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1988.
1640.inscription:
inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.: 9/57
signed in pencil, below image, L.R.: Peterdi
rights: © The Estate of Gabor F. Peterdi

extended_text.content:
The use of the bullfight as a metaphor for the struggles of humanity was common to Picasso’s painted and printed work of the 1930s and was carried forward by Peterdi in the Black Bull portfolio.

“The spiritual movement of surrealism helped to liberate for me a desire for lyricism and romanticism. I associated the movement with memories of my childhood and the result—these bulls and roosters, awakened from the peace of my childhood into the bloody turbulence of life today.”

Gabor Peterdi, 1939
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

1640.exhibit_history: "Gabor Peterdi", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 01/11/2013-01/05/2014

1641.title: Death of the Matador
1641.provenance: Purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1988.
1641.inscription:
signed in pencil, below image, L.R.:  Peterdi
inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.:  9/57
rights: © The Estate of Gabor F. Peterdi

extended_text.content:
The Black Bull portfolio was published in Paris by the art dealer Jeanne Bucher in July 1939, only two months before the outbreak of World War II in Europe.

This portfolio of seven engravings with a bullfighting theme is typical of the engravings produced at Stanley William Hayter’s Atelier 17 and similar to the works of its most famous habitué, Pablo Picasso. His monumental 1937 anti-war canvas, Guernica, which lamented the slaughter of the ongoing Spanish Civil War, was an obvious model for Peterdi’s series.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

1641.exhibit_history: "Gabor Peterdi", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 01/11/2013-01/05/2014

1643.title: The Arena
1643.provenance: Purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1988.
1643.inscription:
inscribed in pencil, below image, L.L.:  9/57
signed in pencil, below image, L.R.:  Peterdi
rights: © The Estate of Gabor F. Peterdi

extended_text.content: Immediately after the publication of the Black Bull portfolio in the summer of 1939, Peterdi, anticipating the imminent onset of war, left France for the United States. The prints were included in his first American one-man show held that November at Julien Levy Gallery in New York, which promoted European Surrealism.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

1643.exhibit_history: "Gabor Peterdi", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 01/11/2013-01/05/2014

2436.title: Breaking Wave
2436.credit_line: Gift of the Contemporary Art Society

25085.title: christening dress (lace)
25085.description: cotton with linen bobbin lace (Valenciennes) and cotton machin-made trim
25085.credit_line: Anonymous gift in memory of Mary Albert Ellis, Scholar, teacher, and restorer of lace
25085.provenance:
Ananonymous, New York {1}; IMA (1989).
{1} in memory of Mary Albert Ellis, scholar, teacher and restorer of lace

extended_text.content: While the garment is probably American, the laces in this christening dress are French in origin. Typical of Valenciennes laces, narrow inserts are sewn together to create wider pieces. There are two types of medallions on the dress: on with wreaths, the other with flowers. The flower medallion pattern is repeated in the ruffles. The cotton embroidered trim is machine-made.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

25085.exhibit_history:
The Romance of Real Lace
August 1993---January 1994
November 1999---August 2000

32871.title: Old Church, Ranchos de Taos
32871.credit_line: Gift of Estate of Marion Patterson Beard
32871.provenance: The artist, Marion Patterson Beard; Estate of Marion Patterson Beard; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1989.
32871.inscription: signed in ink, L.L.:  Marion L. Patterson

extended_text.content:
The massive old adobe church at Ranchos de Taos is among the most painted and photographed buildings in the United States.

Beard, a lifelong Indiana resident and art teacher at Vincennes High School, travelled to New Mexico, Mexico and Guatemala in search of subjects which she exhibited annually with the American Watercolor Society in the 1940s.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

32871.exhibit_history: "Looking West", Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, IN, 2/3/2012-8/5/2012
